docs.lead_paragraph: DARREL SEIFE felt as if he had lost an old friend. Out near the road, a V-shaped trunk was all that remained of the towering oak tree that had stood at the foot of his driveway since long before his arrival at the house 10 years ago. Where branches once arched high and shadows dappled on the pavement, a stump now sat awkwardly like a giant slingshot. ''At first, it seemed like a good idea,'' Mr. Seife, still in mourning, said of the town officials who had told him they needed to take the tree down because it might not be stable. He could have accepted the responsibility for it and had it braced, but that would have made him liable had it fallen on someone. Still, the empty space in the yard loomed before him, a painful reminder.

headline.main: They're Splendid, Except When They Fall

docs.abstract: Article on financial dilemmas that municipalities in Westchester County, NY, often face over large, treasured trees close to highways and roadways, which could become liabilities for municipalities as well as homeowners when they fall; Greenburgh, Yonkers and some other towns are instituting tree-inspection programs in wake of two fatal accidents and subsequent lawsuits; Greenburgh has increased its liability insurance to $21 million from $4 million, has earmarked about $100,000 for tree removal, inspects trees on daily basis and has removed about 100 trees in last year; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''SEX life for women doesn't end with the menopause,'' wrote Dr. Alex Comfort in ''The Joy of Sex,'' his landmark self-help book from the 1970's, ''unless they have been convinced that it should.'' Unfortunately, quite a few women fall into that category. Although 10 percent of a group of women in midlife who were tracked by researchers at Pennsylvania State University said they were having better sex than when they were young, about 60 percent reported a loss of sexual desire, responsiveness or frequency.

headline.main: Sex Without Estrogen: Remedies For the Midlife Mind and Body

docs.abstract: Article on issues of sex, hormones and menopause, with some advice for women (special section, Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. Now Playing * ''CARANDIRU,'' starring Luiz Carlos Vasconcelos. Directed by Hector Babenco. (R, 146 minutes; in Portuguese, with English subtitles). The human life teeming through this sprawling portrait of Brazil's criminal class crowded within a notorious penitentiary exudes a throbbing flesh-and-blood intensity that's so compelling it's impossible to avert your eyes. Watching this messy epic is a little like being jammed into an un-air-conditioned subway car on a steamy summer night as it rattles through an urban wasteland: at any second, things could explode. And eventually they do. It is the 1980's, and the setting is São Paulo's real-life house of detention, which was torn down in 2002, a decade after a riot led to the massacre of 111 inmates by the police. The film is a splashy return to form by the celebrated director of ''Pixote'' and ''Kiss of the Spider Woman.'' In examining social ills, it interweaves multiple stories of the prisoners' lives as viewed by a doctor volunteering his services. Below its documentarylike sprawl, ''Carandiru'' is a hands-on movie passionately engaged in its characters' personal dramas. Just when it threatens to go soft, it erupts in what may be the most horrific prison riot ever filmed (Stephen Holden).
